Expectation1: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation1: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: You are scheduled to be a guest on a live radio show to discuss your cause, and the segment starts in five minutes.
Story: I stare at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the project timeline half-filled, my mind racing. Management is waiting for my estimates—firm numbers that will shape the entire quarter. I know how critical this is; the team depends on my accuracy, and any delay could throw off the roadmap. My phone buzzes. It’s a reminder: the radio show starts in five minutes. As an activist, I’ve been given a rare chance to reach thousands, to educate and inspire action for our cause. I can’t let the movement down, not when so many are counting on me to speak up. But the pressure from work is crushing. I feel my chest tighten, torn between the responsibility to my colleagues and the urgency of my activism. Both roles demand my full attention, right now. My hands hover over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I try to decide which expectation I’ll have to let down.
